dialogues.text: (tense) Seal looks good. I'm equalizing the outer chamber. Carefully he opens a bleed valve, a HISS of AIR as the final link is pressurized. Cahill studies the gauges, consulting his watch. Taking a deep breath, he gently opens the final hatch, swinging it down into the chamber.

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: I'm opening the hatch... He opens the hatch, revealing the belly of the 747 and the avionics hatch, surrounded by the heavy neoprene vacuum-collar. Cahill releases the locking device on the 747 hatch, lowering it into the tunnel. Quickly, urged by Baker, he scrambles up the ladder and inside the 747 as Baker follows, quickly placing the steel clip over a switch, closing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flashing yellow light on the dash winks off. The First Officer thumps it with his finger.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST OFFICER
dialogues.text: Short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Running crosswise to the plane, the nerve-center of the aircraft housing the flight recorder, transmitters, receivers and the main electrical connectors. Cahill climbs into the room, reaching down to grab a bag. Below, Travis stands at the ladder, directing the boarding. Grant follows Baker, who has already begun attaching a series of electrical leads to the ship's power supply in preparation for his equipment. Seconds later, Rat scrambles into the room, followed by Charlie. But as Charlie enters the hatch, his pack catches on the clip securing the warning switch, the clip falling unseen into the door frame.

dialogues.speaker: INT. 747
dialogues.text: Hassan walks towards first class and the stairway.  83 84 85 thru 87 88 51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light on the dash winks on again, catching the attention of the Captain and First Officer. The Terrorist guard, standing behind them, still holding a gun on the pilot, also notices the light.

dialogues.speaker: TERRORIST
dialogues.text: What is that light? The First Officer thumps it with his finger.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST OFFICER
dialogues.text: Warning light, indicating an open hatch in the avionics room.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Which is impossible with the plane pressurized. Must be a short.

dialogues.speaker: TERRORIST
dialogues.text: Where is this room?

dialogues.speaker: FIRST OFFICER
dialogues.text: About ten feet below us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rat grabs a case from the tunnel, swinging it inside. As he turns back he sees the open switch on the hatch. Frantically he searches for the clip, finding it in the doorframe. Digging it out with his fingers, he replaces it over the switch. He looks up at the ceiling as if in anticipation...

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 85
dialogues.text: thru 87

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The yellow light on the dash winks off again.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Off again. Got to be a short. Just then the plane is buffeted by turbulence, Ali stumbling into the room. He seems highly agitated.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Why are we not climbing?!  89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The team waits a moment for the buffeting to cease and then Charlie reaches down into the tunnel, pulling up one of the electronics cases. Cappy has just cleared the hatch and is starting to rise to his feet, both hands on equipment bags, when the PLANE is HIT by windshear, a sudden and VIOLENT SHOCK as the plane falls several hundred feet before it bottoms out on solid air. With the impact, Rat is thrown off balance, his body slamming into Cappy, sending him airborne across the narrow room.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 89A
dialogues.text: A DIZZYING RAPID DOLLY TOWARDS an electrical panel con- taining the high voltage bus bars and circuit breakers for the aircraft's heavy electrical system.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE 89B
dialogues.text: Cappy, arms forward, smashes into panel, his right hand splintering a plastic safety cover protecting a huge, high voltage fuse, a blinding EXPLOSION of sparks and flames as his hand hits the fuse. Instantly, Cappy is blown backwards, the back of his neck slamming into the corner of a steel equipment rack. He falls to the floor, his hand smoking, his sleeve on fire. Baker leaps on Cappy, smothering the fire with his body, Cappy's face in contorted, agonizing pain, barely resist- ing the primitive urge to scream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Flight Engineer throws a series of switches, pro- viding backup power to the cabin lights, blown by the fuse.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: What the hell...

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ENGINEER
dialogues.text: Damned if I know. We blew something big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MASSIVE SHOCK hits the plane, knocking Catman, and Doc to the floor. Travis looks up into the tunnel, be- ginning to climb.  53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Captain is arguing with Ali Hassan.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: +. I'm telling you, without radar I can't climb into another corridor filled with east-bound traffic. But if we hit another pocket of windsheer, we could fall ten, twenty thousand feet... As another wave of TURBULENCE HITS, Hassan looks around him, at the airframe and then to the pilots.

dialogues.speaker: ALI HASSAN
dialogues.text: Climb. Turn the radar on. Suddenly the other Terrorist interjects.

dialogues.speaker: TERRORIST
dialogues.text: (subtitles) Ali. It's a trick. We turn on the radar, they can find us. They'll discover us when we turn back. The plan was not to...

dialogues.speaker: ALI HASSAN
dialogues.text: (to Captain) Climb. Now. Turn on the radar. The Flight Engineer switches on the radar. Ali's lieu- tenant is obviously enraged at this infringement of their plans.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Stand-by, we're climbing... He begins to pull back on the controls...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a WARNING BUZZER SOUNDS. The Pilot checks his instruments.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: Load on the sleeve increasing... Jesus, they're climbing! He grabs the stick...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Travis, nearing the top of the tunnel when the PLANE is HIT by a sudden buffeting, knocking him from the ladder, just as two of the heavy equipment cases fall from above, wedging in the tunnel just above him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SHRILL ALARM sounds as the plane pitches violently to starboard.

dialogues.speaker: CO-PILOT
dialogues.text: We're losing pressure on number six pump. Go with him, keep climbing!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. 747
dialogues.text: The delivery plane sags sharply to starboard, STRESSING the sleeve and the docking seal. The PLANE begins to BUFFET and CHATTER wildly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant, nearest the tunnel, struggles to pull the cases from the tunnel when there is a LOUD HISSING of AIR as one of the pumps begins to fail. Cahill pushes his way INTO the SCENE, looking down into the tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: (panic) We're losing the seal! Hurry! With a combined effort, Charlie, Rat and Grant, pull the gear from the tunnel and onto the floor, as Cahill stares into the tunnel, frozen, listening to the increas- ed VOLUME of HISSING. Grant frees the last of the gear, seeing Travis, fighting to climb up the ladder. Grant extends his arm.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: Colonel! The HISSING INCREASES, the seal threatening to go. Travis looks up, realizing...

dialogues.speaker: TRAVIS
dialogues.text: Close the hatch! (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Grant hesitates, still extending his arm.

dialogues.speaker: TRAVIS
dialogues.text: We're losing it! Close the god-damned hatch... With the SCREAM of the failing SEAL increasing by the second, Travis scrambles down the tunnel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Travis at the bottom of the tunnel, grabs for the hatch when ANOTHER BUFFETING knocks him aside. He recovers, grabbing the release. As he does he looks up, eyes locking with Grant's, a frozen moment, a look from Travis as if he were entrusting the rest of the mission to Grant And then...

dialogues.speaker: TRAVIS
dialogues.text: Close the hatch!!! Hesitant but obeying, Grant reaches down, closing the hatch to the 747... But as Travis pulls the lower hatched closed, the deliver plane pulls free from the 747. The escaping pressure turns into a SCREAM of AIR, followe by a THUNDEROUS EXPLOSION that rips through the plane. As the tower tears loose, the implosion sucks Travis through the tower as if a leaf in a gale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulls violently away from the 747 and begins to tumble out-of-control as it falls a thousand feet, the TOWER RIPPING apart, followed by one of the wings. An instant later, the plane disintegrates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flying on station, tracking the 747 and the delivery plane. We GO IN ON the revolving radar dish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An OPERATOR sits in front of a radar screen, surrounded by a complex array of radar equipment. On the screen we see the strong, steady blip of the 747, and the fading blip of the delivery plane. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR
dialogues.text: They're gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crisis team is fixated on the overhead screen, plotting the course of the two planes, the course of the delivery plane fading, dropping away. In a moment it blinks from the screen. A RADIO TRANSMISSION from the E2 breaks the stunned silence.

dialogues.speaker: E2-OPERATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Castle Rock, this is Big Eye-6. We have lost all contact with Hail Mary. The Major-General picks up the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: Big Eye-6, this is Castle Rock. Was delivery accomplished?

dialogues.speaker: E2-OPERATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Castle Rock, I can't say. Hail Mary was attempting delivery when contact was lost. A moment of silence, broken by the Director's voice.

dialogues.speaker: DCI
dialogues.text: (quietly) Something must have failed with the airlock and they depressurized. Kaplan turns away from the overhead screen, his eyes cold and hard. He addresses the Admiral.

dialogues.speaker: KAPLAN
dialogues.text: Where is the Task Force, Admiral? The Admiral points to a location on the situation board.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL
dialogues.text: Carrier Task Force Six has been diverted and is heading towards an intercept point in the Atlantic.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: Go to Red Alert. Contact the President. He looks up at the situation board, at the flashing dot, advancing steadily onward towards the United States.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cappy is lying on the floor, his face covered in sweat, writhing in pain as Baker carefully sprays antiseptic over Cappy's burned hand and forearm, wrapping the area with gauze bandages.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Best I can do for now. I've got some morphine, take care of that pain.

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: No... Might need me... Got to stay awake... But as Baker moves Cappy's arm across his chest to isolate it, Cappy inhales sharply in pain.

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: Baker... My neck. Whole left sife... burns like acid. (moves fingers of left hand) All down my arm... Alarmed, Baker carefully feels behind Cappy's neck, gingerly palpitating down his neck, stopping at a point near the shoulder blades. Cappy again winces, nearly fainting from the pain.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: There's a depression, a deformity of C-7... (looks up) He's got a fractured vertebrae. We've got to immobilize him.

dialogues.speaker: INT. 747
dialogues.text: The Flight Engineer is patiently trying to explain to Ali his need to go into the avionics room.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ENGINEER
dialogues.text: We don't know what happened. But I've got to go down there, check it out. We could have a fire, anything.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Where is this room? The Engineer points to a hatch on the floor near the rear of the cockpit. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ENGINEER
dialogues.text: About ten feet below us.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Go ahead. The Engineer opens the hatch, peering down the narrow ten foot shaft, leading through the stairwell bulkhead and into the avionics room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the hatch above them open, light streaming down from above, the men move rapidly for cover, Cappy left where he lays, hidden in the shadows. Anxious looks from the men as they draw their weapons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Flight Engineer descends into the tunnel, Ali standing over him, a flashlight in his hand, the Terrorist Guard pointing a gun at him. The Engineer looks at the gun.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ENGINEER
dialogues.text: Relax. I'm not going anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Engineer enters the darkened, cramped room, moving towards the electrical panel. He shines a tiny flash- light on the broken fuse cover, examining the destruction with a puzzled look. Suddenly he grows wary, slowly turning, looking down at the floor, into the shadows and Cappy's sweating, pain-racked face. He's about to speak when he looks up, directly into Rat's face, a pistol pointed at him. Dumbstruck the Engineer watches as Rat indicates silence, then points to the small American Flag on his shoulder. The Engineer looks around, seeing other faces, staring at him, weapons pointed. Rat gestures to the panel, then upwards towards the cock- pit, as if to say, "Hurry up." The Engineer turns back, throwing a switch, replaces the fuse, then restores the power to the fuse. Again, Rat gestures for silence, offering the okay" sign. The Engineer numbly nods his understanding and moves back to the ladder. He looks up into the cockpit, Ali standing above, shining a flashlight on him. The Engineer climbs the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: INT. 747
dialogues.text: The Engineer enters the room, closing the hatch. The Pilot turns.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: Everything okay down there?

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ENGINEER
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh, yeah. Just a blown fuse. Must have been the turbulence. The Pilot seems puzzled by this but the Engineer turns and sits at his station, staring at his instruments, stil in shock at what he has just seen below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cappy has been strapped to a blackboard made from a bulk- head panel. Cahill, looking pale and stunned, watches with Grant as Rat and Charlie hold Cappy's head as Baker places a makeshift cervical collar of foam insulation around Cappy's neck. Baker then carefully tapes Cappy's head and shoulders to the blackboard. Cappy closes his eyes, resting. A silence descends on the tiny room.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (quietly) What about Travis, the others?

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: (numb) The plane depressurized. At this altitude,, the airframe would have collapsed, like an egg shell. They couldn't have... The team is silent, stunned by the reality of their situation.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Now what? We've got no radio, half the equipment...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We're fucked, that's what. Cahill suddenly panics.

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: They don't know we're here. Think we're all dead... (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (realizes) They're going to blow us out of the sky! Cahill turns to them, panic filling his face.

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: We have to negotiate with them. Tell them they know about their plot, they'll never let them reach the United States. It's our only chance. Rat, assessing their situation, speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: I'm in charge, Cahill. Sit down and shut up. (beat) There's only one thing we can do. Take over the plane, let them know we're in command and then land it some place safe. As planned.

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: Look at you. There's nothing left. You've got no chance. We're the only ones who know they aren't going to make it. They have to listen... Rat reaches out, grabbing Cahill by the shirt, yanking him forward, nose to nose.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: (coolly) Get a grip, Cahill. (beat) We're all in the this together, so just hang with us and do what you're told. Now sit your ass down and stay put. Stunned but under control, Cahill nods, Rat releasing him. Silence settles over the room, the men now realizing there is but one choice facing them.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: All right. We need to know how many, where they are, how they're armed. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: We should set up the probes, mikes. (nods to Grant) Let the Captain here have a listen. Could be a dozen of them, we don't know.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: Okay. What's left of the gear?

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Not much. No radio, scanners, sleep agent, only half the weapons. We've got fiber optic probes and mikes, infra-red goggles, bomb kit. That's it.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: And no one to fly the plane. What's our time frame? Baker consults a Plexiglass card, three analog watches indicating elapsed time; time on board; time to fail safe, the sweep hands moving at steady, unstoppable speed.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Unless a change in speed and course, we've got three hours and forty-eight minutes.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: All right. We figure out where they are, how to hit em. He points to the power control boxes on the bulkheads.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: Power for lights, everything is right here. We blow the lights, use infra-red to hit em hard while they're still surprised. (beat) Let's get started. Again, Grant's cautious warning sounds out.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: You're forgetting something.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: What's that? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: The bomb.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: We'll worry about that after we take the plane. We can't spare the time to look for it.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: I don't think you can afford not to...

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: (irritated) Let's get one thing straight, Captain. You're still along as an advisor. Stick with the interpreting. When I need your opinion, you'll know it.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: It's more complicated than chain of command. Finding that bomb is just as important, maybe more, than taking over this plane. Think about it. From his stretcher, Cappy calls out.

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: He's right. Got to know if there's a bomb. (beat) Could be a pressure switch, timer. Try to land the plane, change altitude, anything could set it off. Don't know what you're dealing with. Got to find it. The men look to Rat for a decision. Rat looks at Cappy, then to Grant. He nods.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: We'll look for it while we're setting up. Charlie, tools and bomb kit. Get started.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. 747
dialogues.text: Moves silently above the clouds, 36,000 feet above the Atlantic.  103 104 105 106 107 108 63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Flight Engineer is staring at the hatch on the floor, leading to the Avionics Room. He looks up at the terrorist guard in the doorway and then to the pilots, a look of frustration on his face. He's dying to tell them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rat, reaching the bulkhead leading to the forward galley, uses a pair of hydraulically powered shears to cut through the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carefully pushing aside the bulkhead, Rat, gun in hand, enters the galley. Seeing the blanket on the floor, he pulls it back, finding the dead attendant. He replaces the blanket, going to the elevator door, carefully opening it. Seeing that the lift is above him on the main cabin level, he begins to cut the rivet heads from the floor using his shears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Baker, using a heavily padded, nearly silent ELECTRIC DRILL, bores a tiny hole into the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a section of carpet as the ceramic tip of the drill silently emerges at a forward angle. As we PULL BACK, we realize that the drill has just missed the boot of one of the terrorist guards. An inch in the other direction...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Removing the ceramic bit, Baker inserts into one of the two holes he has drilled a spike microphone and into the other, a fiber-optic probe. He plugs the microphone into his com-unit. On the viewscope he sees two huge boots, grossly distorted by the wide-angle lens.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Shit. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A moment later, the boots move forward, the form of the terrorist revealed as he walks past the passengers, pausing at the work station by the staircase leading to the upper level.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: (to mike) Got one. First class cabin. W.2Z. 63 machine gun, grenade, and 9mm pistol. As he continues to watch, the terrorist from the cockpit, descends the staircase to talk. Baker switches on a tiny bug mike and we faintly hear the CONVERSATION in ARABIC..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant is seated before a fold-out, portable control panel a series of lights and switches indicating the various locations of the highly sensitive spike mikes. Grant writes: "First Class" on a piece of tape, sticking it on the board. He listens to the conversation in Arabic.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: (to headset) Sounds like one more on guard in the upstairs cockpit and business class area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Rat, suspended upside-down, attached to a special harness to a thin cable, strung the entire length of the plane, pulls himself along on silent rollers, a human gondola. The air temperature is cold enough to fog the breath.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: (to headset) Okay, I'll check it out. I'm at mid-cabin. Hold on... He stops, twisting to his side, pushing the viewscope probe and mike through a joint in one of the ceiling panels.

dialogues.speaker: THE CABIN BELOW 110A
dialogues.text: Seen through the wide-angle lens, the rows of passengers directly below him. The probe moves, revealing more sections of the cabin, holding on the mid-section galley area where four terrorists, including Ali Hassan, are gathered, listening to the SHORT-WAVE and MILITARY RADIOS

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: (to headset) Four in the main cabin, listening to a radio. Two others, in the aisles. Machine guns, side arms, grenades.

dialogues.speaker: AVIONICS ROOM
dialogues.text: Grant is now listening to the conversations in Arabic from the mid-cabin area.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: (to headset) They're waiting for a report on Jaffa's takeoff from London. Sounds like they'll contact them on their own frequency.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 112
dialogues.text: thru 116

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran enters and begins preparing coffee. She removes a packet of coffee from a drawer, dumping the old coffee filter in the trash. She searches for a new filter, and finding none, reaches to an overhead cabinet, opening it. As she does, Ali's coat, hung over the aprons, falls to the floor. As she bends to pick it up, a folded map falls to the floor. Fran can see that it is an aeronautical navigation map, part of the Washington, D.C. area exposed Cautiously Fran opens the map, seeing an air corridor approaching the Washington airport where the White House and other government buildings are located, heavily circled in red marker, the notation: "2,000 feet," in handwriting. She studies the map and then carefully refolds it, replacing it in the inside pocket. As she stands, Ali walks into the room. Fran looks at the coat.

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. It fell when I opened the cabinet. (gestures to open cabinet) I was getting some coffee filters. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He reaches out, taking the coat. He checks inside, seeing the tip of the map in the inside pocket. He reaches to his waistband, his hand closing on the handle of his pistol, the move hidden by the coat.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: How are the passengers? Are they comfortable?

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: They're... very scared, but under the circumstances doing well. Ali's eyes, probing, searching.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: It's important they remain calm. Is there anything they need?

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: No. They just want this to be over with.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Soon enough. A few more hours. I will share something with you, but it must remain between us. (studying her) When we land... in London. We will be releasing the women and children. Fran stares at him, knowing this is a lie.

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: That would be very kind. He studies at her a long moment, then removes his hand from the gun, folding the coat.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: I'm keeping you from your work. He turns and leaves. Fran stares ahead, her hands trembling. She knows something horrible is going to happen with this highjacking and she has to do something. But what? She sees the empty clipboard where the manifest had been, thinks, and then removes from her apron her ballpoint pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The air temperature also cold enough to fog the breath. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Charlie, using a sophisticated array of bomb detection equipment to locate the presence of explosives and magnetic and electrical fields, makes his way over the tops of the baggage containers. He stops, carefully moving one of the probes over a container. He adjusts the sensitivity of the instrument and then keys his mike.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (to headset) Rat. Forward baggage compartment. Got something.

dialogues.speaker: RAT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (filtered) I'm on my way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran walks down the aisle, stopping at a seat. Fora moment, all we see are the brown leather boots of the Air Marshal.

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: I believe you're next, sir. The AIR MARSHAL, early 30s, mustache, dark hair, looks up, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: The bathrooms. You're next. Something in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: AIR MARSHAL
dialogues.text: Thank you. As he rises she moves away, face close to his, whisper- ing, barely audible.

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: (whispering) Razor blades... She turns to the passenger across the aisle, leaving the Marshal bewildered over her phrase as he heads down the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. 747
dialogues.text: As we TRACK ALONGSIDE the massive airframe, HOLDING ON the section just aft of the wing juncture.  119 68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We MOVE ACROSS the tops of baggage containers, barely two feet of clearance overhead. Tiny lights have been clipped to the ceiling, illuminating the darkened room with red light. We ARRIVE at a container, opened up like a soup can, baggage strewn everywhere. Overhead lights illuminate the open container as if it were the crater at Tycho in 2001. Inside is Rat and Charlie. Charlie examines some- thing in the container with his detector.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Almost missed it. Reading was less than one part in two million. Inside we see a dismantled wooden packing crate, revealin a three-tiered object, at the bottom of which are two rows of double-ended bottles, two feet long, six inches in diameter, stacked two deep, a total of 12 bottles. The surface of the bottles is a shiny, metallic material, like mirrored sunglasses. Strapped to the canisters with stainless steel bands, is a black metal box, two feet high.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: Whatever it is, it's sittin' on enough Semtex to fuck up your whole day.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (nervously) Let's do it. Using a hand-powered drill, Rat carefully drills a tiny hole into the case. He attaches a fiber-optic probe, peering through the eyepiece. He looks up.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: Take a look. Charlie uses the probe to examine the container. He looks up, confused.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Way out of my league. Rat studies the interior again, thinks a moment and then keys his mike.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: (to mike) Captain, you know anything about bombs?  120

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant at the com-board, listening to Rat.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: A lot of theory.

dialogues.speaker: RAT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There's something I want you to look at -- forward baggage compartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Air Marshal waits near the bathrooms, a Terrorist on guard. A passenger leaves one of the bathrooms, the Guard gesturing to the Marshal to enter.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Thirty seconds. The Marshal enters, attempting to close the door, the Guard shoving his foot INTO the FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Leave it open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaving the door slightly ajar, the Marshal faces the toilet, eyes searching the room, focusing on the tiny sign near the sink: "DISPOSE OF RAZOR BLADES HERE." Still facing the toilet he opens the tiny disposal box, removing a folded slip of paper. He reads: Plane going to Wash. D.C. Target White House. Do something." Behind him the DOOR EXPLODES OPEN, the Marshal dropping the paper into the toilet...

dialogues.speaker: TERRORIST
dialogues.text: Too long! Back to your seat! The Marshal bends to flush, the note stuck to the bowl near the top. He FLUSHES, the water flowing over the note, still stuck. He FLUSHES AGAIN...

dialogues.speaker: TERRORIST
dialogues.text: Out! The Terrorist yanks the Marshal around, just as the water catches the paper, swirling it down the toilet.  121 122 70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant eases into the pit, replacing Charlie. He takes the probe from Rat, studying the interior of the bomb a moment before standing. He looks puzzled, very worried.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: (quietly) You'd better get Cappy.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: We can't move him.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: I don't think you've got any other choice. Rat considers this and then nods to Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Arab Diplomat and an Assistant are in the room. The Secretary of State, the DCI and Kaplan enter the room. The Diplomat hands a document to Kaplan who grimly reads its contents.

dialogues.speaker: ARAB DIPLOMAT
dialogues.text: The man who designed the bomb is most probably Jean-Paul Demou. That's a recent photograph. He's French, nuclear engineer, once assigned to a reactor plant in Damascus, Syria. His wife, a Syrian national, was killed during an Israeli attack on the plant, three years ago. Kaplan hands the document to the DCI then offers his hand to the Arab.

dialogues.speaker: KAPLAN
dialogues.text: Thank you for your help. Please excuse me. He takes the two men aside.

dialogues.speaker: KAPLAN
dialogues.text: It's confirmed.

dialogues.speaker: DCI
dialogues.text: Twelve canisters and at least fifteen pounds of plastic explosives. We're dealing with a potential kill-factor of a low- yield nuclear weapon. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY OF STATE
dialogues.text: Then we have no other choice.

dialogues.speaker: KAPLAN
dialogues.text: As per the orders of the President, instruct Admiral Crosby to go to full alert. When he's in range, he's to launch his strike aircraft. Authorize the press release for the B.B.C. as per Ali's instructions.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY OF STATE
dialogues.text: If we have to shoot down the 747, why release Jaffa at all?

dialogues.speaker: DCI
dialogues.text: We have to take Ali's word that there will be more bombings in London if he's not airborne by three.

dialogues.speaker: KAPLAN
dialogues.text: Contact Ambassador Hennings in London. I want to deliver a message to Jaffa. I want him to negotiate with Ali Hassan. Tell him we know of Ali's plot, that we will exchange the lives of the passengers for Ali's, if he will divert to an isolated airbase. Jaffa's the only one who knows the frequencies to contact Ali. (beat) I'm not giving up on those four hundred Americans. That madman is our last avenue of hope. We've got to try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somewhere in the Atlantic. Several F-14's are being readied for flight, deadly Sidewinder missiles fitted to their racks, magazines of .20MM cannon rounds loaded into place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baker, Charlie, Rat and Cahill carefully move the makeshift stretcher with Cappy strapped in place, over the tops of the baggage containers. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Working on hands and knees, they lift, move and pass the stretcher along, straining and sweating in the close confinement. The stretcher is placed alongside the open container, Cappy grimacing in pain from the movement.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: Sorry to do this to you, Cappy. But we've got a bad one here.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: It's some form of computer controlled triggering device, very sophisticated.

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: (in pain) Let me have a look. Baker attaches a second eyepiece to the unit, holding one to Cappy's eye as he squeezes the trigger. Grant observes the interior along with Cappy.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BOMB 124A
dialogues.text: In the eerie illumination of the probe is revealed a forest of printed circuit boards, and in one section, a rotating laser-disc-like mechanism, connected through a series of relays and wires to a thick floor of dark orange material at the base of the computer, sitting directly atop the nerve gas.

dialogues.speaker: RETURN TO SCENE 124B
dialogues.text: Cappy studying the bomb.

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: Micro-processor, dedicated fixed drive, least 40 megabytes... could be running a dozen programs... Cappy now sees the guts of the bomb, the lens moving around, showing the relays and probes, pressed into the plastic explosive at the base.

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: Take me in a little closer... As the lens zooms in and moves around the interior, Cappy grows more concerned and focused by the second. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: Sweet Jesus... nerve gas, binary canisters... Plastic in two pound blocks, sixteen pounds more or less, enough to atomize this plane... Guy doesn't fuck around. This ain't no pipe-bomb and a six volt battery. (beat) This is major-league talent. The lens plays across a glass tube with several elements inside.

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: Now what is this? Stop. Go in on that. Right there. (beat) Now that's something I do recognize. Barometric pressure switch. Activated on take-off, probably set to air-burst during landing. (beat) Could be the way in. Looks like an isolated trigger. If I can... if you can disable that switch, it might buy you some time. Grant stands, looking into the faces of the men grouped around him. Rat ponders the situation.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: Okay, we go as planned. We shut this thing down, take over the plane and get it to someplace safe.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Who gets to fuck with the mousetrap? They're stumped on this one. Grant speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: Cahill.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: (stunned) Cahill?

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: He's the best qualified and the only one you can spare. (looks at bomb) He's a design engineer. He builds stuff like this all the time. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: Except it doesn't go boom if you fuck up. (thinks) What the hell. All right, it's your baby. The rest of us, let's get in position. Charlie, mid- cabin. Baker, rear compartments. I'll take the cockpit, business class. Keep your units on. Let's go. The commandos depart leaving Grant and Cappy behind. Grant turns to Cappy.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: So what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: Honestly?

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: Honestly.

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: We're all lookin' up the ass end of a dead dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off to one side, Grant is talking to Cahill, who stares at him, dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: Jesus. I don't know anything about bombs. I can't do it. Why me? Why not you?

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: I'm the only one who can monitor their conversations. You're all we've got left. (beat) Look at it this way, you've built computers before, haven't you?

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Yes, but what does that have...

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: Now you're going to take one apart. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: But what if I...

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: Make a mistake? Don't worry about it, Cahill, you'll never know it. (beat) You can do it, Cahill. Now let's get going, I've got work to do. Grant pats Cahill on the shoulder. He moves over the cargo containers towards the bomb where Cappy lies, Cahill reluctantly following.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: All right, Cappy. Walk him through it. Call me if you need any help. Grant leaves.

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Cahill, this is just like playing with Leggos, but more exciting. Bring that bomb kit over here and let's get started. Cahill slides the bomb kit into position.

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: First things first. Looks like that black cover is just a lead shield. See if you can lift it off... But, Cahill, everything real easy, okay? Grant carefully releases the four spring-latches at the base of the cover. He removes the fiber-optic probe and then gently lifts the cover, revealing the bomb in its entirety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the Terrorist Guard now downstairs, the Flight Engineer is trying to tell the disbelieving pilots what he witnessed earlier.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ENGINEER
dialogues.text: (urgent; whispering) I'm telling you, I saw them. Americans... He hears the GUARD ASCENDING the stairs and APPROACHING the cockpit. He turns back to his work station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the Marshal ponders his dilemma, carefully studying the positions of the Terrorists, trying to formulate a plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant is on the com-board, headset on, monitoring the various microphones and serving as the link to the team. He keys a switch labeled "CAHILL."

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: Cahill. How you doing? INT. BAGGAGE COMPARTMENT - DAY 126 Cahill is huddled over the bomb, Cappy's bomb-kit open beside him, an electronic detector attached to the wires near the barometric switch. A mirror, taken from a vanity case, has been attached to Cappy's stretcher by an aluminum pole, somewhat like a rear-view mirror. From his position, Cappy can supervise Cahill's work on the bomb.

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: (to mike) Uh, okay, I guess. We're ready to start. (to Cappy) Cappy. The meter indicates 15 oms.

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: Okay, that's good. Looks like it's in parallel and isolated. Go ahead and complete the by-pass. Cahill attaches the end of an alligator clip to the right side of the switch, completing a by-pass loop of the unit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM ABOVE, we see the floor of the elevator pushed upward, revealing Rat in the lower galley. With the skill of a gymnast he carefully wedges his way upward into the elevator, holding his body against the wall as he closes the floor panel. Holding tight to the wall, he carefully peers out the elevator window, seeing Fran, her back to him, working at the galley.  128 129 130 131

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran catches sight of a movement, reflected in the polished surface of the stainless steel wall. Startled, she turns and before Rat can duck, their eyes meet, a look of total shock registering on her face. The flag is visible on Rat's shoulder as he puts his finger to his lips. Suddenly Fran hears SOMEONE APPROACHING from behind, Ali appearing. A moment's hesitation and then she turns, grabbing a coffee urn and a cup. Putting her back to the elevator window, she offers Ali a cup of coffee. He stares at her suspiciously and then accepts the coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rat rapidly turns his attention to the overhead panel. Pulling the panel downward, he pulls himself into the upper section, reaching down to close the panel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ali sips the coffee, studying Fran. He's very uneasy about something but he can't put his finger on it. Finally he moves on. Fran looks around her, and then cautiously shoots a glance inside the elevator. It's empty. We FOLLOW her gaze UPWARDS to the overhead panels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Above the coach section, the longest open space of the plane, consisting of support struts and ribs for the ceiling structure; air conditioning units; ducting, wiring and hydraulic lines. Rat is crouched on one knee, closing the top panel to the elevator shaft.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: (to mike) Shit, I was made. Attendant saw me in the elevator. (beat) Grant, you copy this?

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: I copy. Describe her. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: RAT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (urgent) She's working the mid-cabin. Short blonde hair, five six.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: Okay. I'll have Baker keep an eye on her. All we can do is watch, hope she can keep a secret. (switches ) Baker...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rat continues on, spider-walking along the support beams, reaching up to clip in to the trolley cable when his foot hits a patch of grease, his foot flying out from under hi In one cat-like movement, Rat flips his position, catchin himself spread-eagled over the lower support beams, directly over the plastic ceiling panels for the main cabin. Sweat drips from his face as he carefully regains his position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran studies the ceiling, half-expecting the commando seen earlier to come crashing through to the floor. She looks at Ali, some distance behind her, watching her, unaware of the disturbance she has just heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Rat, moving down the cable, approaching the forward- most section of the plane, Charlie's voice cuts in.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (filtered) I'm in position, mid-cabin. They're all over the place. I can take two, maybe three. I'm good, but I ain't that good. We need another gun.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: Okay, stand by. I'm at the forward section. Let's see how bad it is up there. He moves on, pulling himself along the cable towards the forward section.  134

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant wipes the sweat from his brow and taking a pair of clippers from Cahill, moves his hand into the heart of the bomb.

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: Cahill, could you adjust the mirror? I want to take a better look at this thing. (Cahill adjusts mirror) That's better. Now, clip the wires on either side. Don't touch anything else. Cahill places the cutter around the wire. He hesitates and then, clips the wire, watching the om meter, the needle darting slightly and then holding on: 15 oms. Relieved, he clips the second wire.

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: Good work. That should do it. Relieved, Cahill sits back, keying his com-unit.

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: (to mike) We've isolated the pressure switch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant switches from Cahill on the "B" channel to the "A" channel.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: Rat, this is Grant. They've isolated the switch.

dialogues.speaker: RAT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Thanks. All right, everyone in final positions. Captain, I need to see you in the forward galley, right away. Grant seems puzzled by this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A light mist is falling on the tarmac where a Lear jet is being serviced by a flight crew. Long range, wing-tip fuel tanks are being installed. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A Mercedes sedan, darkened windows, pulls alongside, accompanied by a military escort. Three Arabs emerge from the car, two obviously pilots, carrying flight bags, the other, a grim-faced MAN dressed in a tailored suit. From the plane, a MECHANIC emerges, descending the stairs the name on his coveralls reading: Reggie. He addresses the three men in a heavy Cockney accent.

dialogues.speaker: MECHANIC
dialogues.text: (grinning) She's all yours, China-plate. The Mechanic moves on, the grim-faced Man turning to the pilots, speaking in Arabic.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (subtitles) Search it. Everything. The pilots enter the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside a commercial aviation building, now serving as a heavily guarded holding room for Jaffa. Soldiers and security men are everywhere. Seated on a couch, ina darkened side of the room, is Jaffa, wearing a belly- chain and handcuffs. The U.S. AMBASSADOR to England is speaking to Jaffa, two marine guards standing nearby.

dialogues.speaker: AMBASSADOR
dialogues.text: ... If they will divert to Gander Air Force Base, Newfoundland, the United States will guarantee the safe passage of Ali and his men back to the Middle East. (beat) Otherwise, he will never be allowed to reach the shores of the United States. Jaffa studies the Ambassador appraisingly. He may be in chains but beginning to relish the power attending his new found importance. He smiles, assuming a diplomatic air.

dialogues.speaker: JAFFA
dialogues.text: Ali is an impassioned man, but in the interests of peace, I will do my best.

dialogues.speaker: AMBASSADOR
dialogues.text: I am sure you will.  137 138 139 140 81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rat and Grant are conferring off to one side of the elevator, just below the emergency escape hatch, leading to the main cabin aisle above. Rat hands Grant a hand shotgun, the size of a flare gun.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: There's just too many of them, Captain. We need another gun. Grant looks at the weapon.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: It's been years since I even handled a gun...

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: Don't worry, with this you can't miss. One guy on station just above us. I'll cue you, you'll have the element of surprise. Rat grabs the escape handle to the hatch in one hand, holding the weapon tight to his chest in the other.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: Hold it tight, like this. Push up hard, two steps up the ladder, aim straight at his chest and fire. Don't think, just shoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the squadron of F-14's are launched from the catapults SCREAMING upward, silver messengers of death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Directly behind business class. Rat emerges from a service hatch, easing to the floor inside the closet. Cautiously he parts the two doors, looking into the business class compartment and the cockpit just beyond.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: (to mike) In the business class closet. I'll be set in about thirty seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baker, suspended upside down, moves quickly and silently down the cable, heading toward the rear of the plane, passing Charlie as he goes.  141 142 143 144 82.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant moves into position, under the emergency escape hatch, leading to the aisle of the coach section. He grasps the overhead handle which will push the door up. He stares at the weapon in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: RAT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (filtered) I'll take the man in the cockpit first, then down the stairs for the second. You all move ten seconds later. Baker, Charlie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baker is positioned over the floor, holding open a panel, looking down into the rear-most cluster of bathrooms.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: (to mike) I'm in position. Rear bathrooms. Baker eases down into the room, taking up position at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Charlie has placed a circle of detonation cord on the floor. He's positioned on a support beam above the ceiling panel, holding the detonating switch in his hand. He looks prepared to jump after he blows the floor.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (to mike) Charlie. Ready to blow the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rat, his hand on the doors, is holding a silenced .22 automatic pistol. Through a crack in the door he can see the Terrorist standing several feet away, his back to him.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: (whisper) Okay, dude is right in my sights. Here we go...  83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant releases the safety on the deadly-looking hand shotgun, his hand trembling. He nervously double-checks the unfamiliar weapon, making sure it is cocked. He closes his eyes, blinking away the sweat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the four Terrorists are grouped, listening to the radios. A NEWS BROADCAST is underway on the SHORTWAVE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cahill sitting beside the bomb as Cappy studies it through his mirror. Suddenly a series of red lights flash in sequence on a unit in the center of the bomb.

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: What the hell was that?

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: (startled) I don't know. Looked like some kind of... The lights flash again.

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: Jesus Murphy. Stop them, Cahill. Stop the hit!

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: (in pain) Use the radio. Tell them to stop the hit. Now! Cahill fumbles for the channel switch on the com-unit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rat pushes the door open further, lowering his pistol, sighting down on the head of the Terrorist, a few feet away. His finger starts to squeeze the trigger... Suddenly Cahill's frantic voice breaks in. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (filtered) Stop! Stop the attack! Stop the attack! As the Terrorist starts to turn, Rat pulls back inside, silently closing the door. He wipes the sweat from his face.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant closes the escape hatch, collapsing to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: RAT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (filtered) Cahill, what the fuck is going on?!

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (filtered) He said to stop. Cappy. He said to stop you.

dialogues.speaker: RAT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (filtered) Cappy. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cahill is holding the com-unit to Cappy's head.

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: (urgent) You see any terrorist with anything looks like a transmitter, box, wires, anything?

dialogues.speaker: RAT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (filtered) No. Just weapons.

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: Well, someone just ran a program test on the bomb. Whoever he is, he's holding an override switch, and he's got his finger right on the god-damned trigger... Cahill closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DEVICE
dialogues.text: A hand touches a key and a series of green lights flash in series.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flying in formation, waiting their turn to top off their fuel tanks from a carrier launched A-6 Tanker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaplan and his entourage enter the room, Kaplan staring at the overhead screens and the situation board showing the 747's flight path across the Atlantic. The Secretary of State approaches.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY OF STATE
dialogues.text: We have less than five minutes to make the release.

dialogues.speaker: KAPLAN
dialogues.text: Authorize it. Notify the press. He turns to the Major-General.

dialogues.speaker: KAPLAN
dialogues.text: General.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR-GENERAL
dialogues.text: They'll reach our air space in an hour and a half.

dialogues.speaker: KAPLAN
dialogues.text: It's up to Jaffa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a LEAR EXECUTIVE JET SCREAMS down the runway, lifting off into the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaffa sits in one of the plush cabin seats. The Arab in the tailored suit humbly approaches, speaking quietly in Arabic.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (subtitles) We have contact with Ali. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He pulls a telephone from its cradle and hands it to Jaffa. We hear STATIC FAINTLY over the line, then a voice.

dialogues.speaker: ALI HASSAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (filtered) I rejoice in your freedom. Allah has blessed us. A great destiny awaits us both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crisis team are grouped around the communication center, listening to the conversation as the NSA's scanners keep track of the radio transmission.

dialogues.speaker: JAFFA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (filtered) Listen carefully, the Americans have a message... (beat) They are preparing to meet your demands in Washington. They will give you fuel and gold for the hostages. But do not trust them. Continue radio silence, make no attempt to contact them. (beat) A glorious victory. You have done well.

dialogues.speaker: INT. 747
dialogues.text: Ali Hassan is listening on the field radio to Jaffa.

dialogues.speaker: ALI HASSAN
dialogues.text: In a few hours, you will see how truly glorious my victory will be...

dialogues.speaker: JAFFA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (interrupting) We cannot talk now. They must not locate this frequency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaffa terminates the call, hears the STATIC as the connection is severed. He returns the telephone to its cradle, a cold, menacing look as he turns to the window. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: JAFFA
dialogues.text: Go with God. He jots down several items on a tablet and turns to his new charge de affairs.

dialogues.speaker: JAFFA
dialogues.text: You will prepare an anonymous news release. In several hours, a C.S.A. 747 will be destroyed as it approaches the United States. (hands over the paper) This is the Arab country responsible for the highjacking and destruction of the plane. The necessary proof will be provided shortly. (thinks) Then contact General Hammad. Tell him I have a proposition to make. He sits back, a cold smile forming on his lips.

dialogues.speaker: JAFFA
dialogues.text: I taught you well, Ali.

dialogues.speaker: INT. 747
dialogues.text: Ali Hassan turns OFF the RADIO shouting a revolutionary slogan, the other Terrorists taking up the cry. At this, terror sweeps through the plane. Ali Hassan is now truly a man possessed with carrying out his destiny, and with it, the lives of thousands of innocent people. Hassan turns and looks at someone in the seats before him, a passenger, someone unseen to us. He gives a slight nod and then moves on, shouting another cry of revenge. We HOLD ON Fran as she looks from the frightened faces of the passengers to the overhead panels, aware that some inescapable collision between these madmen and some unseen force infiltrating the airplane is about to happen But who are they, how did they get here, when will they strike?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaplan turns angrily away from the center. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DCI
dialogues.text: (stunned) He didn't even make the attempt. He wants him to die.

dialogues.speaker: KAPLAN
dialogues.text: He's forcing the President to destroy the plane, hoping we'll retaliate.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY OF STATE
dialogues.text: Against whom?

dialogues.speaker: KAPLAN
dialogues.text: Whomever he chooses to implicate.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY OF STATE
dialogues.text: I say we shoot the bastard down.

dialogues.speaker: KAPLAN
dialogues.text: If only we could. They'll stick to civilian air corridors, and we could never violate the foreign airspace anyway. It would be an act of war. Kaplan turns away, staring at the situation board, show- ing the 747 growing closer to the fail-safe line every second.

dialogues.speaker: KAPLAN
dialogues.text: Tell Admiral Crosby to intercept the 747. Then contact the President. From this point on its an executive decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the INTERCOM, the news of Jaffa's release has been broadcast to the terrorist guard. As he takes up the cry, the Flight Engineer looks down at the hatch leading to the avionics room.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ENGINEER
dialogues.text: (to himself) Any time, guys.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. 747
dialogues.text: The giant plane flies on over the Atlantic.  163 164 165 89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Rat, Grant, Charlie and Baker sit in the nose section, assessing their situation in urgent, whispered voices. Grant is monitoring the activities in the cabin area via one of the microphones left in place. He is listening to a CONVERSATION in ARABIC.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: Quiet... sounds like something big's going on. Grant continues to listen.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: (puzzled) One of our boys is challenging Ali. Wants to know why they're not returning to London, now that Jaffa's been released.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: London?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kahlil is arguing with Ali in Arabic.

dialogues.speaker: KAHLIL
dialogues.text: (subtitles) This was not the plan! With Jaffa's release, we were to return to London. This is insane. We must turn back... Suddenly Ali flies into a rage, brutally whipping Kahlil with his pistol, blow after blow, driving him to the floor, killing him. Ali looks up, madness raging in his eyes. Several other terrorists look at him in total fear.

dialogues.speaker: ALI HASSAN
dialogues.text: Traitor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant puts down the headset, looks at the others.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: I think he just killed one of his own men. The others don't know about the bomb. (realizes) Of course. The trigger man is one of the passengers. A sleeper. It could be anyone. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Four hundred passengers. Never find him. We're as good as dead. A long moment as this new reality settles in.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Then I say we go out slingin' some lead. Get some fuckin' payback.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: That's not what we came here to do.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Shit, man, they're gonna blow us out of the sky. At least we can have the pleasure of doin' these bastards before we all buy it. (beat) Hell, we might even get lucky. Rat looks at the men, confused as to what the next plan of attack should be, realizing he has nothing left to offer. He's out of ideas, sinking into the utter hope- lessness of their situation. He looks at Grant, who stares at the floor, deep in thought.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: Captain. (as Grant looks up) Any ideas? Grant looks at his watch. Thinks a moment.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: We might still have some time. And there just might be a way to find the sleeper. (beat) But we've got to keep dismantling the bomb. If we can neutralize it, then finding the sleeper won't matter. But we can't risk it. Have to do both.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And how do we find this sleeper?

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: Baker, what about the video equipment, what do you have? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Wide angle probe, hard-line cable but no camera, monitor, relay...

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: We've got to monitor that cabin. I need to hear everything, see as much as I can. Anything we can use from the plane? Baker thinks, slowly nodding his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baker and Charlie have opened up another of the baggage containers. Charlie hands up an aluminum suitcase to Baker, who opens it, studying the contents.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: This will do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rat carefully drills a tiny hole by hand through one of the bulkheads. He attaches a long cable to the two electrical leads on the end of a six-inch long lens, the diameter of a pencil. Carefully he begins to push the lens into the hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near the flight attendant's work station. Above the center bulkhead we MOVE IN on a tiny hole, seeing a sligh reflector of light as the wide angle lens of the video probe is pushed into position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant is talking to Cappy, Cahill sitting alongside them at the bomb site.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: How bad is it?

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: Short strokes -- it's a masterpiece. Set up on three stages; several back-ups. Pressure switch was designed to trigger as the plane landed. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If that failed, there's a timer operated by the fixed disc. Probably the flight time plus an hour or two.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: Can we disable it? Cut the power?

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: He's way ahead of you. Two power sources, one protects the other. Tamper-proof. Cut one, the second one sets off the bomb.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: Cappy, how are we going to beat this god-damned thing?

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: This guy's good, real good... but I'm better. Won't be easy, but there's a way. Grant turns to Cahill.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: We're going to do everything we can to find the sleeper, but it may all come down to you. You're going to have to go the distance.

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: (numb) As if I had a chance.

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: Don't worry about my man, Cahill, he's got what it takes. (beat) Besides, he fucks up, I'll kill him. Grant pats Cahill on the shoulder. He moves over the containers towards the Avionics Room, leaving Cahill to stare at the bomb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baker is working on a home video Minicam, the aluminum suitcase open beside him. He has opened up the camera and is wiring in a small electrical harness. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He closes up the camera, taping it together. He has removed the eyepiece, exposing the tiny viewscreen inside Rat appears, trailing out the hard-wire video feed, attached to the probe above.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: Ran the cable down the back side of the elevator shaft. They'll never see it. Baker takes the cable, twisting the wires into those leading from the camera. He switches on the camera. On the tiny view screen of the camera, we see the wide angle, black and white image of the main cable. Random static crosses the picture.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Not much resolution, but it works. Grant pats him on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: Now we've got eyes and ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran is preparing several trays of juice and water for the passengers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant, Rat and Baker are watching Fran on the tiny screen

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: She's on a short leash, but has the freedom to move around the cabin... Grant looks to Rat for approval of his plan.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: All right. Try it. Baker hands Grant a switch, wired into the electrical system of the plane. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: I've by-passed the buzzer.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: Let's hope she sees it. Grant activates the switch. On the video monitor we see that a light on the telephone is flashing a code. A moment later, Fran notices the light, but stares at it, unmoving.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: Pick it up... pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran staring at the flashing light. She looks around, seeing one of the Terrorist Guards standing nearby. She looks at the flashing light... and then picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: Just listen. I'm watching you on a video. Behind you, above the bulkhead. Disbelieving she turns, eyes searching, focusing on the tiny probe, barely visible in the bulkhead.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: We're Americans. You've seen one of us. There is a bomb on this plane. One of the passengers is in direct control of it. We have to find him and we need your help. You're looking for someone with an electronic device, a radio... Suddenly the phone is ripped from her hand, Ali roughly spinning her around.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Ali places the phone to his ear and listens. The line is dead.

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: I... thought the phone rang. I'm sorry. It's just habit. He stares at her and then hangs up the phone. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: You always have an explanation. Ali leaves. Fran is overwhelmed by this new development. Suddenly she remembers, the Air Marshal. She looks back down the aisle, making eye contact with him. She turns back, horrified. She has to warn him, but how?

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: (to herself) Think... She looks around her, focusing on a rack of magazines. We HOLD ON Fran's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant and Baker watching the tiny screen, watching as she moves around the work station.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: She looks pretty shaken. I don't think she'll do it.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: She's got to. They continue to watch as Fran picks up a stack of magazines and turns towards them. A moment's hesitation and then she looks up, directly into the lens, a look of strength and determination on her face, she nods. Grant turns to Baker.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: She's with us. Lady's a player. A momentary look from Rat, a nod of acceptance. Grant is now in charge.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: Good move, Captain. I'll get upstairs, watch her. If she fingers someone, we'll have to move fast. Rat leaves via the flap leading to the baggage compart- ment. Baker looks at his tac-board. We PUSH IN ON the watches, the elapsed timer running down to forty-five minutes remaining.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: We reach U.S. airspace in forty- five minutes.  175 176 177 178 96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran is moving down the aisle, carefully scrutinizing any visible carry-on luggage, bags and seat pockets for some sign of a suspicious device, all the while pretending to look after the needs of the passengers, offering them Magazines to read. Behind her, a Terrorist Guard keeps a close watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULLING BACK FROM the situation map, showing the 747's position, now approaching the U.S. The Major-General hangs up a telephone and addresses the Kaplan.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR-GENERAL
dialogues.text: The F-14's should be intercepting the 747 in approximately fifteen minutes. Should be coming on the board any second. On the screen we see, four small points of light, approaching the 747 from a converging angle, their origin somewhere near Florida.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran approaches the Air Marshal, who looks up briefly. She reaches his seat, casually handing him a magazine. What the quard can't see is her expression as she taps th cover of the magazine. The Marshal looks down seeing: A Newsweek, a cover shot of a group of U.S. soldiers in camouflage, weapons, the banner-line reading: "HOW MUCH

dialogues.speaker: LONGER."
dialogues.text: The Marshal looks up, Fran looking hard at the picture and then mouthing the words: "They're here." She moves on, leaving the Marshal to stare at the picture in bewilderment. They're here? Fran continues to search for some sign of suspicious behavior, an electronic device, something. There seems to be nothing but row upon row of frightened, innocent- looking passengers.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 178
dialogues.text: view of the bomb FOCUSES on a wiring harness of varying colors. The tiny, pinpoint beam of a laser appears on one of the wires. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: Low-power, number one. Just touch the wire for a heartbeat. In Cahill's hand is a laser-knife, the size of a fountain pen, a wire leading to a power box on the floor beside him. Cahill touches the trigger and the beam changes intensity, the wire suddenly vaporizing, leaving the bare wire underneath exposed.

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: That's good. Now clip in. Cahill wipes the sweat from his brow, his shirt soaked in perspiration. At his side is a small black box, taken from the bomb kit. At one end of the box are a series of ports for electrical connections. Several wires lead from the ports to the bomb, clipped in to wires in various components.

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: Here goes... With trembling hands, he attaches another wire to a relay in the bomb, plugging the other end into the black box.

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: Outstanding. You've got the major sensors by-passed. Mr X will still think the bomb's intact. (beat) Kick the power up to three and cut the wires to that first relay. That's a load-fluctuator, a fail- safe against an electromagnetic burst. Cahill turns up the power and begins to move the laser- knife towards the bomb. But his hand begins to tremble uncontrollably. He stops.

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: (verge of panic; anger) I can't do it. My hand's shaking too much. I can't breathe.

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: Settle down, Cahill. You're doing fine. You know anything about fishing? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: (numb) No... I hate fish. Hate the outdoors.

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter. Shut the fuck up and listen. (beat) Take a deep breath. Relax. Close your eyes. (beat) You're sitting at your desk... it's in the middle of a pine forest. Wind cool and light, the sun shining down through the trees. You're beside a stream, water rollin' over the rocks into the most beautiful pool of deep, green water you've ever seen... Cahill's breathing slows, his face beginning to relax. Cappy closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: ... You get up from your desk and walk to the pool, your fly rod in your hand, royal coachman tied on, your can't miss fly. At the back of that pool is Bad Leroy Brown, fifteen pound German trout, just startin' to rise from beneath a tangle of logs. Now, all you got to do is pull back, float your line out, lay that fly down like a feather, right in front of old Leroy's nose... Cahill opens his eyes. His hand has stopped shaking. He moves forward, cutting through the wires with the laser.

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: (relieved) I did it. He turns, looking at Cappy's face, reflected in the mirror. Cappy nods, closing his eyes in relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran is moving down the aisle, the Terrorist Guard strolling close behind. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As she passes a seat, a hand reaches out, tugging on her apron. Startled, Fran turns. It's the heavy-set Woman seen earlier. The Woman is perspiring and seems short of breath.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Miss, may I have some water? I have to take my medication. Diabetes. The Woman holds out a prescription pill vial.

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: (distracted) Of course. I'll get you some water. The Woman fumbles with the vial, her hands trembling.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: These things are always so hard to open... The vial slips from her hands, falling to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: I'll get it. Fran kneels to the floor to help. The Guard moves in, prodding her with his weapon.

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: (calmly) It's all right. I'm just getting her pills. Fran kneels, searching the floor for the vial, finding it next to the Woman's feet. She is about to rise when her eyes freeze on the underseat storage space of the window seat, where the Laptop Computer, seen earlier, sits, nearly obscured from view. Fran stares at the computer, slowly looking up into the alarmed eyes of the dark-complected man at the window. The Guard pulls Fran to her feet, examining the pill vial before giving it to the Woman.

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: I'll be right back with your water. The man at the window follows their movement and then carefully removes the computer, hiding it between his body and the window bulkhead.  180 181 182 183 184 100.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran, with her BACK TO US, a terrorist standing nearby, appears to be replenishing her drink tray, pulling down paper cups from an overhead bin and working on something before her. But as we move alongside her, we see that between movements, she hurriedly scribbles something on the back of the tray with a lipstick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON the TV monitor, showing Fran just inside the galley. As one of the Terrorist Guards passes by, she turns back to her station, busying herself with some- thing. She turns back, and while looking at the probe, brushes her ear several times, looking around her.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Captain, take a look at this. Grant studies the monitor as Fran again brushes her ear.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: She's signaling. On the monitor we see a Terrorist Guard as he slowly moves through the galley, crossing behind Fran. Lifting the tray off the counter, Fran turns towards the camera, flipping the bottom upwards as she does. On the bottom of the tray, written in red lipstick, we see: 148-B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant and Baker studying a schematic of the passenger section of the plane. Baker circles a section, Grant keying his mike.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: Rat, we've got something. 148-B. Window seat, mid-section.

dialogues.speaker: RAT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (filtered) I got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somewhere over the Atlantic, flying in tight formation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The NAVIGATOR plotting a course on his radar screen. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: NAVIGATOR
dialogues.text: Have target acquisition at three hundred miles, vector zero-six- zero for contact.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: Roger. Formation this is Bulldog. We have radar contact, turning zero-six-zero for contact. Initiate weapons systems check now. Notify me on visual contact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rat, using the fiber-optic viewscope, is lying on his stomach, observing something below. He is wedged into an impossibly tight position, under an air-conditioning vent. CLOSE ON the monitor as the fiber-optic probe pans across the heavy-set Woman's legs, zooming in on small computer, tucked against the leg and the seat of the man in 148-B.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: Could be a small computer, between his leg and the seat. Looks like he's hiding it. All I can see is his legs. Air conditioning unit, right in the way. But the computer is definitely suspicious. It has to be him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (filtered) Can you get a hit on him? Rat looks away from the fiber-optic probe, staring at the bulkhead, inches from his face.

dialogues.speaker: RAT
dialogues.text: Can't move up here, barely breathe, no hope for a shot. Charlie, what about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie is positioned near the mid-section restrooms in the crawl-space above the doorways. Lying on his side he is able to peer through the fresh air vents, providing a view of passengers. Although he can see the man in 148-B, he is barely visible behind a passenger sitting in front of him. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Towards the rear, another terrorist is plainly visible. Charlie's pistol is at his side.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No chance. Blocked by the seats, passengers all around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cahill has isolated the wires leading to a major relay of the bomb, a harness of wires, situated near the fixed disc, the disc rotating silently behind the glass obser- vation window. Cahill approaches the wires with the laser beam. Cappy is watching Cahill's movement through the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
dialogues.text: We're almost home. Next stop is a little tougher. Relax. Just do what I tell you. (beat) The red one on top, first. Then, separate the wires with the spreader, cut the yellow one underneath. Just kiss that red one like a feather. Don't touch the other wires. (beat) Take your time. Slow and steady. As the laser-knife begins to glow, Cahill slowly lowers it to the first wire, beginning to cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON hands as they open the computer-like device. Fingers touch the keyboard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, on the bomb, there a series of electical relays on the testing unit flashing Cahill's hand jumps, slicing is a metallic CLATTER as open and close, the lights in series... through half of the harness. His face goes rigid with fear as we CRASH ZOOM to the rotation disc as it abruptly Cahill inhales sharply... halts. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cappy staring wide-eyed into the mirror, sweat pouring down his face, waiting for the bomb to explode. But the frozen disc, Cahill's trembling hand, remain fixed in the mirror. Cappy's mind is racing. He exhales sharply.

dialogues.speaker: CAPPY
